case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Heirs and legal representatives of Amarchand N. Shroff

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 15 to 19 of 1962 were filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE, JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 15 to 19 of 1962.

facts.text: Appeal from the Judgment and order dated October 10, 1958, of the Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 22 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the Judgment and order dated October 10, 1958, of the Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 22 of 1958.

facts.text: Amarchand N. Shroff, Mangaldas and Hiralal were partners in a firm of solicitors.

anchor.surface_text: Shortly stated the facts of the case are these Amarchand N. Shroff, Mangaldas and Hiralal were partners in a firm of solicitors.

facts.text: Amarchand died on July 7, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Amarchand died on July 7, 1949. Thereafter the partnership was carried on by Mangaldas and Hiralal up to November 30, 1949,

facts.text: Partnership carried on by Mangaldas and Hiralal up to November 30, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the partnership was carried on by Mangaldas and Hiralal up to November 30, 1949, and on December 1, 1949,

facts.text: Ramesh son of Amarchand joined the firm as the third partner on December 1, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: and on December 1, 1949, Ramesh son of Amarchand who had by then qualified as a solicitor joined the firm as the third partner.

facts.text: Firm kept its accounts on cash basis.

anchor.surface_text: The firm kept its accounts on cash basis. For the five assessment years 1950- 51 to 1954-55 the following amounts

facts.text: For assessment years 1950-51 to 1954-55, heirs received Rs. 37,847, Rs. 43,162, Rs. 34,899, Rs. 13,402 and Rs. 32,523 out of outstandings.

anchor.surface_text: For the five assessment years 1950-51 to 1954-55 the following amounts were received Rs. 37,847/-, Rs. 43,162/-, Rs. 34,899/-, Rs. 13,402/- and Rs. 32,523/- by the heirs

facts.text: Income-tax Officer sought to tax these realisations.

anchor.surface_text: by the heirs and legal representatives of Amarchand out of the outstandings. The Income-tax Officer sought to tax these realisations.

facts.text: For 1950-51 and 1951-52, ITO assessed amounts in hands of heirs as Hindu undivided family.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer sought to tax these realisations. For the assessment years 1950-51 and 1951-52 he assessed the amounts in the hands of the heirs and legal representatives

facts.text: Appeal taken to Appellate Assistant Commissioner and then to Appellate Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: as a Hindu undivided family. Against that order an appeal was taken to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and then to the Appellate Tribunal.

facts.text: Tribunal held amounts not income of Hindu undivided family but inheritance or realisations of assets of Amarchand.

anchor.surface_text: The two members of the Tribunal agreed in holding, though for different reasons, that the amounts were not the income of the Hindu undivided family but merely represented inheritance

facts.text: Revenue did not pursue further initially.

anchor.surface_text: or realisations of the assets of Amarchand. The matter was not pursued further by the Revenue but sometime later

facts.text: Proceedings started under s.34 by ITO in hands of Amarchand N. Shroff by his heirs as individual.

anchor.surface_text: but sometime later proceedings were started by the Income-tax Officer under s. 34 in respect of the same income in the hands of Amarchand N. Shroff by his heirs

facts.text: Assessments made under s.34(b) read with s.24B for 1950-51 to 1954-55.

anchor.surface_text: The various amounts were assessed to income-tax in the hands of the respondents under s. 34 (b) read with s. 24B of the Income-tax Act.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner held notice under s.34 valid only for 1950-51, quashed for 1951-52 to 1954-55.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal the Appellate Assistant Commissioner held that the notice under s. 34 could validly be served only for the assessment years 1950-51 and notices

facts.text: Commissioner appealed to Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: for the subsequent years were invalid. The assessments for 1951-52 to 1954-55 were therefore quashed. The Commissioner of Income-tax took an appeal

facts.text: Tribunal held assessment could not be made on Amarchand, s.24B had no application, capital receipt not revenue.

anchor.surface_text: to the Appellate Tribunal and the Tribunal held that assessment could not be made on Amarchand and that s. 24B had no application to the income received after

facts.text: Commissioner applied for reference to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: the death of Amarchand and that it was capital receipt and not revenue receipt. ... On the application of the Commissioner of Income-tax

facts.text: High Court referred question: Whether the sums ... were assessable ... under reference? Answered in negative.

anchor.surface_text: the following question of law was referred to the High Court - Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the sums of Rs. 37,847/-, ... The High Court answered the question in the negative.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered on October 23, 1962 by KAPUR, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. October, 23. The judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR, J.-These appeals pursuant to a certificate

facts.text: Arrangement: realisations of work up to death of Amarchand divided amongst Amarchand, Mangaldas, Hiralal.

anchor.surface_text: After the death of Amarchand the arrangement between the various partners in regard to the realisations of the old outstandings was that in respect of the work done up to the death

facts.text: Realisations for work July 8, 1949 to Nov 30, 1949 divided between Mangaldas and Hiralal.

anchor.surface_text: of Amarchand the realisations were to be divided amongst Amarchand, Mangaldas and Hiralal, in respect of the work between July 8, 1949, and November 30, 1949,

facts.text: Realisations after Dec 1, 1949 divided amongst Mangaldas, Hiralal and Ramesh.

anchor.surface_text: the realisations were to be divided between Mangaldas and Hiralal and in respect of work done after December 1, 1949, the realisations were to be divided amongst

arguments.claim: On a correct interpretation of s. 24B the amounts received by the heirs after death should be deemed income received by Amarchand and liable to tax under s. 24B(1)

anchor.surface_text: It was argued by counsel for the Commissioner of Income-tax that on a correct interpretation of s. 24B the amounts which were received by the heirs and legal representatives of Amarchand after his death should be deemed by the fiction incorporated in sub-s. 1 to be income received by Amarchand and liable to tax under s. 24B 1 of the Income- tax Act.

arguments.claim: Respondents liable to pay tax out of estate as deceased would have if not died, emphasis on s.24B(1) words 'or any tax which would have been payable by him under this Act if he had not died'

anchor.surface_text: In other words the respondents as heirs and legal representatives of the deceased Amarchand were liable to pay out of the estate of the deceased Amarchand on those amounts to the extent of the estate as the estate was liable for tax on the amounts received by the heirs and legal representatives just as the deceased Amarchand would have been had he not died. The emphasis was on words in s. 24B 1 or any tax which would have been payable by him under this Act if he had not died.

anchor.surface_text: But this interpretation is not in accord with the language used in s.24B. All the sub-sections have to be read together. arguments.claim: s.24B(1) words confined to income received before death or after but in previous year

anchor.surface_text: The second part or the words above quoted when read with sub-ss 2 and 3 show that they are confined to cases therein mentioned. They show that those words also have to be restricted to the income received by the deceased person before his death and to the income received after his death by his heirs and legal representatives but in the previous year

arguments.claim: Legal fiction in s.24B limited to purpose; cannot extend beyond previous year

anchor.surface_text: By s. 24B the Legal personality of a deceased assessee is extended for the duration of the entire previous year in the course of which he died and therefore the income received by him before his death and that received by his heirs and legal representatives after his death but in that previous year becomes assessable to income-tax in the relevant assessment year.

arguments.claim: Income-tax exigible only on previous year income; post previous year receipts not liable under s.24B

anchor.surface_text: Income-tax is exigible in reference to a persons total income of the previous year. The question before us is whether the income which was received subsequent to the previous year in which Amarchand died is liable to be assessed to income-tax under s. 24B as his

holdings.text: The sums of Rs. 37,847/-, Rs. 43,162/-, Rs. 34,899/-, Rs. 13,402/- and Rs. 32,523/- were not assessable to income-tax in the hands of the assessee Amarchand N. Shroff by his legal heirs and representatives in the five respective years under reference.

anchor.surface_text: In our view the High Court rightly answered the question in the negative and against the Commissioner of Income-tax.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.24B liability limited to income up to previous year of death; post-year receipts not deemed income of deceased; fiction not extended beyond purpose.

holdings.text: Section 24B does not authorise levy of tax on receipts by the legal representatives of a deceased person in the years of assessment succeeding the year of account being the previous year in which such person died.

anchor.surface_text: Section 24B does not authorise levy of tax on receipts by the legal representatives of a deceased person in the years of assessment succeeding the year of account being the previous year in which such person died.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All sub-sections read together confine liability to previous year; legal personality extended only till end of previous year of death.

holdings.text: By s. 24B the legal personality of a deceased assessee is extended for the duration of the entire previous year in the course of which he died and therefore the income received by him before his death and that received by his heirs and legal representatives after his death but in that previous year becomes assessable to income-tax in the relevant assessment year.

anchor.surface_text: By s. 24B the Legal personality of a deceased assessee is extended for the duration of the entire previous year in the course of which he died and therefore the income received by him before his death and that received by his heirs and legal representatives after his death but in that previous year becomes assessable to income-tax in the relevant assessment year.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory fiction limited to purpose of assessing income till end of previous year; citing Bengal Immunity on fictions not extended beyond purpose.

holdings.text: The provisions of s. 24B do not extend to tax liability of the estate of a deceased person beyond the previous or the account year in which that person dies.

anchor.surface_text: The provisions of s. 24B do not extend to tax liability of the estate of a deceased person beyond the previous or the account year in which that person dies.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Income-tax exigible on previous year total income; post-death receipts beyond previous year not attributable to deceased.

holdings.text: All the sub-sections of s.24B have to be read together; words in sub-s.1 confined to income received before death or after but in previous year.

anchor.surface_text: But this interpretation is not in accord with the language used in s.24B. All the sub-sections have to be read together. Sub-section 1 can be divided into two parts (1) where the income of the deceased was assessed before his death and (2) where the income was not so assessed but it would have been liable to tax had he not died.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction limits scope of 'any tax which would have been payable if he had not died' to cases in sub-ss.2 and 3, i.e., previous year income.

holdings.text: Legal fictions are only for a definite purpose and they are limited to the purpose for which they are created and should not be extended beyond that legitimate field.

anchor.surface_text: As was observed by this Court in Bengal Immunity Co. Ltd. v. The State of Bihar legal fictions are only for a definite purpose and they are limited to the purpose for which they are created and should not be extended beyond that legitimate field.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying precedent from Bengal Immunity to limit s.24B fiction to previous year liability.

holdings.text: The amounts which are sought to be taxed and which have been held not to be liable to tax are those which were not received in the previous year and are therefore not liable to tax in the several years of assessment.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the amounts which are sought to be taxed and which have been held not to be liable to tax are those which were not received in the previous year and are therefore not liable to tax in the several years of assessment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cash basis accounting; realisations post previous year not income of deceased; heirs not deemed assessees beyond that year.

anchor.surface_text: See Allen v. Trehearne 1  where the words if he had number died were interpreted. Sub-section  2  provides that if a person dies before the publication of the public numberice under s.22  1  or before a numberice is served on him under sub-ss. 2 of s. 22 or s. 34 then the Income-tax Officer may proceed to companypute or assess the total income of the deceased person as if the heirs and legal representatives were the assessees.

precedents.cited_proposition: interpretation of the words 'if he had not died'

precedents.citation: Ellis C. Reid v. Commissioner of Income- tax, Bombay 1

anchor.surface_text: The section was enacted by the Legislature to bring to tax, after his death, income received during his lifetime, and fill up the lacuna which was pointed out by the High Court in Ellis C. Reid v. Commissioner of Income- tax, Bombay 1 . Any income received in the year subsequent to the previous or the account year cannot be called income received by the person deceased.

precedents.case_name: Ellis C Reid v Commissioner of Income-tax Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: lacuna in the Act before enactment of s 24B regarding assessment after death

precedents.citation: Additional Income-tax Officer v. E. Alfred 2

precedents.case_name: Additional Income-tax Officer v E Alfred

Those observations also are of numberassistance to the Commissioner of Income tax, Kania, J., as he then was  there observed that the question whether a particular amount was income or number had numberhing to do with the time of its receipt

precedents.cited_proposition: question whether a particular amount was income or not had nothing to do with the time of its receipt; receipt material only for year of assessment

anchor.surface_text: Counsel also relied on the observations of Derbyshire, C.J., in re Sreemati Usharani Shoudhurani 1 . In that case the managing agent of a limited companypany died on May 12, 1938. At the time of his death there was a credit with the companypany of a sum of money on account of companymission earned by him and due to him prior to the date of his death.

precedents.cited_proposition: salary due to deceased paid to widow after death in previous year taxable under s 24B

precedents.citation: Ellis C. Reid v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay 2

anchor.surface_text: The companyrect position is that apart from s.24B numberassessment can be made in respect of the income of a person after his death. See Ellis C. Reid v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay 2 . In that case, and that was a case before s. 24B was enacted, a person was served with a numberice under s. 22 2  of the Income-tax Act but numberreturn was made within the period specified and he died.

precedents.case_name: Ellis C Reid v Commissioner of Income-tax Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: no assessment can be made after death apart from s 24B

precedents.citation: Wallace Brothers Co. Ltd. v Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City 2

anchor.surface_text: The individual assessee has ordinarily to be a living person and there can be numberassessment on a dead person and the assessment is a charge in respect of the income of the previous year and number a charge in respect of the income of the year of assessment as measured by the income of the previous year. Wallace Brothers Co. Ltd. v Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City 2 .

precedents.case_name: Wallace Brothers Co Ltd v Commissioner of Income-tax Bombay City
precedents.cited_proposition: assessment is a charge in respect of the income of the previous year and not in respect of the income of the year of assessment

precedents.citation: Bengal Immunity Co. Ltd. v. The State of Bihar 2

anchor.surface_text: By s. 24B the legal representatives have, by fiction of law, become assessees as provided in that section but that fiction cannot be extended beyond the object for which it was enacted. As was observed by this Court in Bengal Immunity Co. Ltd. v. The State of Bihar 2  legal fictions are only for a definite purpose and they are limited to the purpose for which they are created and should number be extended beyond that legitimate field.

precedents.cited_proposition: legal fictions are only for a definite purpose and limited to that purpose and should not be extended beyond

anchor.surface_text: Section 24B does not authorise levy of tax on receipts by the legal representatives of a deceased person in the years of assessment succeeding the year of account being the previous year in which such person died.

anchor.surface_text: By s. 24B the Legal personality of a deceased assessee is extended for the duration of the entire previous year in the course of which he died and therefore the income received by him before his death and that received by his heirs and legal representatives after his death but in that previous year becomes assessable to income-tax in the relevant assessment year.
In our view the High Court rightly answered the question in the negative and against the Commissioner of Income-tax.

anchor.surface_text: But this interpretation is not in accord with the language used in s.24B. All the sub-sections have to be read together. Sub-section 1 can be divided into two parts (1) where the income of the deceased was assessed before his death and (2) where the income was not so assessed but it would have been liable to tax had he not died.
In our view the High Court rightly answered the question in the negative and against the Commissioner of Income-tax.
